results.title: The Beatles Anthology 1. July 1940 to March 1963
results.creator_credit: Chipps Chipperfield, Apple, EMI/Parlophone, Picture Music International and Geoff Wonfor
results.brief_description: This is the scarcely credible beginning of the great adventure going back, back to post-war Liverpool. The Beatles Anthology No.1 traces the lads back to their early musical influences from Elvis to the film “The Girl Can’t Help It” [304613]; their first instruments; a cross-town search for the B7 chord; Paul, George and John meet up; first recordings; Buddy Holly; Stuart Sutcliffe; Ringo and Roy Storm and the Hurricanes; early tours; Pete Best; Hamburg; the Cavern Club; Brian Epstein; new suits; audition with George Martin; Ringo joins the band; their first number one: “Please, Please Me”. See how the forties became the fifties became the sixties and discover how becoming the Beatles became.

results.brief_description: The Beatles touched down in Sydney on June 11, 1964 and for an amazing 13 days they captivated the nation.

results.title: The Beat of distant hearts
results.brief_description: Through various Saharawi artists, poets and singers, this documentary tells the tragic story of the Saharawi nomads who were forced into exile from their homeland, the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara in North-West Africa, by the Moroccan invasion in 1975. For 15 years an armed struggle raged between the occupying Moroccans and the Polisario Front, the national liberation movement of the Saharawis, until 1991 when a ceasefire took place, monitored by the United Nations. Over 170,000 refugee Saharawis live in camps established in the harsh barren desert of Southwestern Algeria. In 1992 the United Nations attempted to sponsor a referendum for the Saharawis to vote for their future in Western Sahara - asking whether the Saharawis wished to remain a part of Morocco or rule themselves. However obstacles and disputes prevented the referendum and subsequent attempts have similarly been thwarted. Eventually it was decided to delay the vote until July 2000. The artists in this story tell of their own personal experiences, their day-to-day life and the effect the conflict has had on their families, and how the ongoing struggle for independence has kept alive their culture and influenced their works. In turn, it has been through their works that they have been able to educate, express and motivate their people to maintain the fight for independence. Director Danielle Smith lived as a member of a large extended family in the Saharawi refugee camps in southwest Algeria and taught English at the Women’s Vocational Centre. Through this experience she gained a close understanding of the culture and society. NB: The color in the film appears faded and washed out and the quality of the lighting to be overexposed. However this tonal condition lends itself to giving the film an air of surrealism.

results.title: The Beat manifesto
results.creator_credit: Shilo McClean, Daniel Nettheim and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Hamish lives on a sheep farm in rural New South Wales, but he dreams of reading his poetry in a New York jazz club. After saving all his money for a ticket to ‘The Big Apple’, Hamish travels to Sydney where he meets aging Beat poet Bill Darcy. Bill offers to help Hamish, preparing him for his New York odyssey by teaching him the rules of the Beat lifestyle. Cast includes Steve Vidler as a cop.
Written by Tony McNamara, Daniel Nettheim and Mathew Schulz.

results.title: The Beast of Monsieur Racine (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Kratky Film, Weston Woods Studios and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Presents an animated adaptation of the story of the same title by Tomi Ungerer in which Monsieur Racine discovers a strange creature in his backyard. Tells how he becomes good friends with the creature but still cannot identify it and relates how he visits the Academy of Science in Paris for help. Animators include Irena Jandova, Milan Klikar, Vera Kudinova, Bohumil Sejda. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Beast must die
results.creator_credit: Amicus Productions, Max J Rosenberg, Milton Subotsky and Paul Annett
results.brief_description: A wealthy and ambitious hunter gathers several guests to his expansive country estate with the intention of revealing that one is a werewolf. Initially baffled by their host’s objective, the visitors soon become terrified that one among them may be a killer beast. Resembling an Agatha Christie mystery, this is a promising set-up, but offers little in the way of clues or intrigue, despite the invitation for audience participation to deduce the killer. The film features Christopher Lee as a lycanthrope expert, and there are 1970s blaxploitation overtones with Calvin Lockhart in the lead role. Also known as “Black werewolf”.

results.title: The Beast = La Bete [DVD] (E)
results.creator_credit: Anatole Dauman, Argos Films and Walerian Borowczyk
results.brief_description: Banned for many years, this erotic re-working of the “Beauty and the Beast” fairytale by Polish director Walerian Borowczyk is a bizarre mix of melodrama, horror, farce, satire, porn and broad humour. On the eve of her wedding, an American heiress, betrothed to the mentally unstable heir of a French aristocratic dynasty, is beset by sexual fantasies about a rapacious beast. Her imagination is triggered by rumours she hears that such a lustful beast lived in the grounds of the estate in the 18th century, and copulated with the beautiful young lady of the house. Borowczyk’s all out assault on social conventions and repressed desires can be seen as signposting both the peak of his sexual fables (Blanche, Immoral Tales), and his subsequent decline into soft porn. Contains graphic sexual imagery. Cast: Sirpa Lane, Lisbeth Hummel, Elisabeth Kahson, Pierre Benedetti, Marcel Dalio. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Bear and the mouse
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, F Remmier and I Remmier
results.brief_description: A variation on Aesop’s classic fable in which mice aid the escape of a bear in return for past favours. Shows real animals doing exactly what the story requires. A bear catches a mouse, but eventually the freed mouse chews an escape route for his trapped benefactor, illustrating the point that the weak can sometimes help the strong. Suitable for Lower Primary level students.
